utterances: First, NPR's Rachel Martin reports from Munich.
The much-anticipated opening day of the World Cup started out quietly, as both German and Costa Rican fans appealed to a higher power to support their respective teams.
Religious officials from around Germany held a special church service at the Frauenkirche Cathedral in Munich's City Center to bless all the 32 World Cup teams and their supporters.
But many German fans at the ceremony expressed more than just faith in their team.
Wearing a top hat with the red, black and yellow stripes of the German flag, Bernard Vilting(ph) said there was no need for prayer.
(Speaking foreign language)
We didn't need to pray for a win, he said, because we know that Germany will win today anyway against Costa Rica.

At Munich's Olympic Stadium, an overflow crowd of roughly 30,000 people packed themselves in front of a huge screen to watch the beginning of the tournament, the first game broadcast live from a few miles away at the Allianz Arena.
(Soundbite of music)
I'm standing on a hill overlooking masses and masses of flags from all over the place - Brazil, Germany, Togo, it looks like, Ivory Coast.
It's just a mass of humanity and an incredible collection of soccer fans from all over the world.
(Soundbite of crowd singing)
The odds were in Germany's favor to win this match, but that didn't mean the Costa Rican fans, like James Perez and his friends, had to surrender their high hopes.
Everyone says that you're going to lose.
Yeah.
That's all right.
Not that they're letting things down.
The pressure is on Germany.
It's not on Costa Rica.
I think we're going to make it.
Maybe into first place.
It's that delirious loyalty, blind faith and sometimes unrealistic expectation that makes the World Cup the most popular sporting event in the world.
It's what you do as a fan, and especially as an underdog like Costa Rica.
The opening game didn't disappoint fans on either side, though.
Germany gave an excellent opening performance in front of their home crowd, but Costa Rica did not give them an easy run and performed better than expected against the dominant home team.
At one point the Costa Ricans were running neck and neck with the Germans at 1 to 1.
Then the Germans rebounded with another two goals to take the lead once more.
But Costa Rica came back with another goal by Paolo Wanchope in the second half, as heard here on ESPN.
Here's Centino(ph).
Pancho to his right.
Pancho making a run.
He gets it inside.
The shot.
It's into the back of the net.
And Costa Rica has struck again for the second time today.
They have cut the lead from three to two.
But just three minutes before the game's end, German midfielder Torsten Frings scored the final goal of the game, clinching the match for Germany.
This is what it sounded like in a Munich bar when it was clear the home team had won the first game of the World Cup, four goals to two.
(Soundbite of applause)
There's a lot of pressure on the host country, not just to win their first game, but to win the tournament.
Speaking before the match, Germany's head coach, Juergen Klinsmann, said it's a challenge that should be greeted as an opportunity.
A World Cup in your own country doesn't happen that soon anymore, so we would like to grab that opportunity.
We would like to take advantage of playing at home.
And then I think the whole country would be extremely happy and proud, but we just want to make sure that we show the people in our country that we give everything we have.
Germany's next game will take place against Poland on June 14th.
German fans are hoping tonight's game is a good omen for the rest of the tournament.
Rachel Martin, NPR News, Munich.
In Jerusalem today, a hospital official said Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon showed a slight improvement.
His condition remains critical but stable.
Sharon suffered a massive stroke and cerebral hemorrhage this week, and medical experts say there's very little chance he could recover enough to return to work.
NPR's Peter Kenyon has an update from Jerusalem.
Hadassah Hospital director Shlomo Mor-Yosef said today's scan revealed that the swelling in Sharon's skull had eased slightly.

He also said basic vital signs were within normal limits, but cautioned that doctors still don't know how much damage was caused by the stroke or the internal bleeding that prompted three emergency operations.
He stressed that the improvement was only in the edema or swelling, which in itself says nothing about the brain's ability to function.
Prime Minister Sharon, as I said, is still at risk.
There is an improvement in the CT scan results, which is a slight improvement in the edema.
We'll be able to tell something about the meaning of this improvement only when we'll slightly reduce the depths of the anesthesia, which we'll do in the next few days.
I have to - couldn't say.
I don't know who the prime minister of India is.
Hog's head, book of the Old Testament.
OK.
Dr.

Mor-Yosef said a team of experts would meet again tomorrow to decide on the course of action for the next 24 hours and they would probably discuss the issue of when to begin to try to arouse the prime minister from his induced coma.
Mor-Yosef said as the anesthesia is reduced, doctors will be looking for some sort of response to pain, to light, something to help them assess brain function.
As Israelis wait for some clear indication of their leader's condition, there's a growing realization that even if he lives, there's almost no chance he could return to office.
Outside the hospital, 35-year-old Derom Demont(ph) reflected the feeling of many Israelis.
(Through Translator) I don't know who will be able to lead the country.
It's like what I call the dinosaurs are going away and I think the situation now is very unclear for the next couple of years.
But the remaining members of Sharon's brand-new and untested Kadima Party are quietly trying to retain as much public support as possible.

Acting Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, the Sharon ally and former Jerusalem mayor, met with elder statesman Shimon Peres, apparently seeking to pre-empt any move by the Labor Party to get Peres back in the fold.
Peres' endorsement of Sharon and his new party last month gave Kadima a powerful boost among Israeli voters looking for a centrist alternative to either Labor or the conservative Likud Party.
Israeli pollster Rafi Smith says the strong showing for Kadima after the news of Sharon's stroke probably reflects initial public shock and sympathy for an ailing leader.
He says that could quickly fade, so Olmert needs to rally the public behind Kadima.
Ehud will have 48 hours to show that he's a new leader here.
Sharon became here like a father--OK?--and in the sense, you know, you have to adapt a new father, it takes time.

Analysts say if Kadima doesn't manage to keep the confidence of voters, Likud and its likely leader, former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, could be the largest beneficiaries, suggesting another right turn in Israeli politics.
Peter Kenyon, NPR News, Jerusalem.
And it's time to play The Puzzle.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Joining us is Will Shortz.
He's puzzle editor of The New York Times and WEEKEND EDITION's puzzlemaster.
Hey, Will.
Good morning, Sue.
All right, Will, remind us of last week's challenge.
Yeah, it was a tough one.
I said name a profession in 13 letters that's associated with a particular five-letter country.
I said the letters of that country appear in left to right order, although not consecutively, in that profession's name.
What is it?
And I said the profession is a single word.
Well, the answer is hieroglyphist...
Oof (ph).
...Which is associated with Egypt.
And the letters E-G-Y-P-T are in left-to-right order - thought very hard - long and hard.
We had a number of listeners send in industrialist, which holds India - didn't decide.
And I didn't think industrialist was quite closely connected enough to India but that was almost.
And some people sent in sheep-shearing to Spain and quartermaster to Qatar, which I thought were interesting but not quite on target enough.
That was a pretty tough puzzle.
Yeah.
Well, we received 215 responses, and our winner this week is Jared Voss of Medford, Mass.
Congratulations, and welcome to the program.
Thank you.
Jared, how did you figure out the week's challenge?
